summary: Peter: A pet rock is a fun pet until you realize that it's essentially immortal and you've damned it to an eternity of watching...
body:
Peter: A pet rock is a fun pet until you realize that it’s essentially immortal and you’ve damned it to an eternity of watching its loved ones die.

Ned: Pete, stop texting me at three in the morning.

summary: Into the Spider-Verse is obviously a masterpiece and having a black Spider-Man is so fucking rad but I’m still losing my shit...
body:
Into the Spider-Verse is obviously a masterpiece and having a black Spider-Man is so fucking rad but I’m still losing my shit over him being biracial?? Like HOLY SHIT I LOVE IT

he’s biracial black/Latino and 😍😍😍 I mean how often do you see a MAIN CHARACTER who’s not only POC but biracial??? My sweet spider baby you’re doing so well ilysm

summary: Best of This Week: The Amazing Spiderman #17 (Legacy #818) Hunted pt. 1 - Nick Spencer, Humberto Ramos, Victor Olazaba, Edgar...
body:
Best of Marvel: Week of March 13th, 2019

Best of This Week: The Amazing Spiderman #17 (Legacy #818) Hunted pt. 1 - Nick Spencer, Humberto Ramos, Victor Olazaba, Edgar Delgado and Joe Caramagna

This first part of Hunted was everything I wanted it to be and more.

Spinning out of Kraven’s Last Hunt and the Grim Hunt storylines, Kraven is a man without purpose and a soul, believing his only way to die is at the hands of a Spider, but not before ridding the world of these costumed fools wearing the skin of animals and having another potentially final battle with Spider-Man.

Humberto Ramos was definitely the right pick for the art of this storyline. His style and Edgar Delgado’s inks set a dark tone for the entirety of the series. Both Kraven and his son are shrouded in dark shadows when they’re introduced, crazed looks in their eyes and it is an amazing sight. Ramos also draws a spectacular fight between Peter and Kraven’s son. As Peter is succumbing to the effects of a noxious gas, the son appears from the shadows. Peter sees three of him and puts up a good fight, but the young Kravinoff is too fast, too strong for Pete and defeats him.

He then wakes up in the middle of Central Park, surrounded by his deadliest enemies, in the costume that truly started this rivalry between Spider-Man and Kraven.

This might be Kraven at his most sane and unhinged states of mind. He’s teamed up with Arcade and makes use of the Planetary Defense Shield, last seen in Secret Empire, to host a giant hunt of most animal themed villains. He also uses Black Cat and Curt Connors son as a lure for Spider-Man, exploiting his weakness for the women he loves and the people of New York in general.

The entirety of Nick Spencer’s run thus far has had me hooked and he’s been sewing the seeds for this story for months. Seeing everything come to fruition and writing it so well that I’m feverishly waiting for each issue is a testament to how good it is. Not only that, but his team of artists, from Ryan Ottley, Iban Coello, Chris Bachalo to Humberto Ramos now has been amazing. Ramos is my favorite Spider-Man artist and I hope that he’s doing the art for however long this arc goes.

—————————————————

…It just gets better and better.

Runner Up: The Punisher #9 (Legacy #237) - Matthew Rosenberg, Szymon Kudranski, Antonio Fabela and Cory Petit

Combining the wackiness and comedy of Mike Baron’s run with the brutality and dark humor of Ennis’ Punisher Max, Matthew Rosenberg and Szymon Kudranski have crafted and amazing, badass action packed Punisher story that sets him loose in what could possibly be the closest place to heaven for him.

Frank and his band of wrongfully imprisoned inmates have mostly taken over Baron Zemo’s prison, when the moralistic inaction to kill some guard of one of the inmates endangers the lives of the rest. In a beautiful few scenes, Frank rains hell down on the few surviving Hydra agents and is confronted by TASKMASTER!

Taskmaster is one of my favorite, underutilized, villains and he doesn’t disappoint here. He sets Frank alight with a flamethrower in an amazingly drawn sequence of panels, utilizing bright, vibrant oranges, dark inks and the colors in Frank’s eyes and Taskmaster’s white cloak stand out but don’t take over the scene. They fight and brawl with Frank able to hold his own against Taskmaster, who is very obviously the superior fighter, but uses his own guile and ingenuity to trip Tasky up a few times. Taskmaster gets the better of Frank, however, but immediately is hit by a truck before he can strike the final blow.

The finals shots we get are the smoldering ruins of the prison with the Hydra Flag planted in the ground, but with a Punisher Skull over it and…the last one is just too much. Too fun. I love it and I think I’m going to love Frank being in Bagalia. It’s going to be insane.
